submission.raw_content:
Title: Sacred Stacks and Post-Extractive Dev Environments

Contribution Overview:
Sacred Stacks is an effort to build software environments that reframe code and digital infrastructure as sacred, relational practice. It proposes a post-extractive model of development where communities can co-create and maintain digital tools grounded in ceremony, kinship, and long-term care. Rather than maximizing speed or efficiency, these environments prioritize collective authorship, slow knowledge, and epistemic sovereignty. Dev environments become cultural environments.
This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3

Directly Addressed Desirable Properties:
- DP2 – Participant Agency and Empowerment: Communities define the epistemologies and protocols that shape their tooling.
- DP4 – Data Sovereignty and Privacy: Local-first principles guide data flows and custodianship.
- DP10 – Education: Learning environments are embedded within the dev stack, encouraging intergenerational transmission.
- DP14 – Trust and Transparency: Transparent rituals and authoring protocols build trust within and across stacks.
- DP20 – Community Ownership: Dev environments are stewarded by the communities they serve.

Clarifications & Extensions:
**DP10 – Education: Slow Knowledge and Intergenerational Contexts**
Extension: Education is treated as a long-term community process. Dev environments support lineage-based learning and non-linear exploration.
Why it matters: Helps shift from extractive, market-based skills training to community-authored knowledge ecosystems.

**DP4 – Data Sovereignty and Privacy: Relational Data Ethics**
Clarification: Data governance models incorporate relational and ceremonial constraints, grounded in community-specific ontologies.
Why it matters: Expands privacy beyond technical boundaries into cultural and ecological relationships.

(End of Submission)
